subject: Re: [junit] Providing test data
msgSnippet: ... In addition to J.B. s good advice, I typically have an Ant task to run the tests with the JVM property necessary to find the root directory. Here s an
messageBody:
"J. B. Rainsberger" wrote:

> One technique I have used is to have a method called "getUnitTestRoot"
> which answers a File object representing the folder where the tests
> should look for files. The path for this root folder is specified when
> the tests are run through a JVM environment property. You will
> eventually push this method up to the superclass of all your unit
> tests. PROS: Every test can call new File(getUnitTestRoot(),
> "relative/path/name") to get a File object for the desired file within
> the correct folder. Tests can be located anywhere on the disk which is
> convenient if the tests run on multiple machines. CONS: You need to
> remember to pass in the property each time you run the tests. Getting
> the path wrong can be annoying with tests failing left and right. You
> generally end up suclassing TestCase and making that subclass the
> parent class of all your tests, which you may find ugly.

In addition to J.B.'s good advice, I typically have an Ant task to run
the tests with the JVM property necessary to find the root directory.
Here's an example for those interested:

<target name="test" depends="compile.tests" if="junit.present">
<junit fork="yes" printsummary="no" haltonfailure="yes">
<jvmarg value="-Dtest.data.dir=${test.data.dir}"/>
<classpath refid="project.classpath" />
<formatter type="plain" usefile="false" />
<test name="${main.test}" />
</junit>
</target>

Mike
